_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Applicable building, electrical, and plumbing codes. This facility complies with the Iowa Fertilizer Law.
_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: We utilize those portions of these codes which are deemed applicable by the jurisdictional authority
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vandalism/theft (methamphetamines). Provisions have been made to install a protective barrier around the plant perimeter to reduce the potential of vehicular damage.
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Flow Limiters=what in the trade is called an excess flow valve. Breakaway couplers have been installed at the risers and a remote emergency shut-off valve installed at the storage tank.
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Regular plant inspections/Routine preventive maintenance & repairs
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Pumps, pump seals, pipes and plumbing, valves, electrical equipment, and safety equipment. The breakaway couplers, pressure relief valves, and hoses are routinely inspected and replaced as necessary.
_prev_prog_2.Description: The plan is to minimize those hazards to human health and to the environment that are associated with accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. Employees working at the bulk storage plant make routine observations prior to and during transfer operations of the anhydrous ammonia from the storage vessel(s) to nurse tanks. In so doing, they are able to detect problems before they arise. This routine inspection identifies any portion of the system which may be under stress or about to fail. Repairs can be made before they become problematic. Employees are annually trained to recognize the hazards associated with storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia. In addition to annual training for employees who have been on the job for a number of years, the company conducts training for new hires. This training includes classroom instruction, on-site training at the plant, and follow-up observation to determine their individual comprehension and understanding of the new hire. Finally, the company routinely invites  local fire department personnel to visit the site. In the event that the local fire department requests assistance in training its employees on anhydrous ammonia, the company cooperates fully in their endeavors.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Landus Cooperative - New Hartford

Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary 



FACILITY POLICY:

Landus Cooperative is committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  Regular inspections and maintenance are required on all storage facilities, loading and unloading facilities, application equipment and portable tanks.  Employees who handle anhydrous ammonia are required to attend bi-annual training which emphasize the properties of anhydrous ammonia, the effects of anhydrous ammonia on the human body, operating procedures, emergency procedures, and emergency first aid.  PPE, including gloves, goggles, hard hats, emergency water, and sturdy work clothes & shoes are required whenever handling anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, this facility is prepared to work with local fire departments, LEPC, law enforcement, or other authorities to mitigate the impact of the release to people and the environment.  



FACILITY INFORMATION:

Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and kept in storage tanks until distributed to customers in mobile nurse tanks for use as a nitrogen fertilizer.  The storage tanks, several anhydrous ammonia nurse tanks, risers for filling the nurse tanks, pumps and controls, lighting and safety equipment are all part of the facilities anhydrous ammonia operation.  The facility is staffed during seasonal operating hours and is secured when not in operation.  Security includes area lighting, closing and locking the main valve (belly valve) from the storage tank(s), locking out power to pumps, closing fill hose end valves and locking them in a box that prevents unauthorized access to them, locking nurse tank unloading valves, and walk-thru inspections.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM:

This facility has implemented the provisions of Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, published by the American National Standards Institute, Inc., the standards of the U.S. Occupa

tional Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) 29 CFR 1910.111 Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, and the Iowa Fertilizer Law.  Annual inspections by Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship (IDALS) are made on facilities and portable nurse tanks. Frequent site inspections are made by management and safety consultants.  Equipment inspections, maintenance and employee training are conducted prior to every application season.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

No accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia have occurred at this facility in the past five years.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:

This facility has a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.38.  The facility has also provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA) and has coordinated with local emergency responders.  



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

Safety improvement is an on-going process at this facility and periodic evaluations are performed to assess conditions. Changes to improve safety at this facility are completed as required by rule change and/or methods to increase safety and/or efficiency of operations.
